ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Picbreeder Status
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks for this very detailed response Ken. I am glad to hear people continue to use the site. I am planning on buying some of the custom products at some

Thanks for this very detailed response Ken.

I am glad to hear people continue to use the site.

I am planning on buying some of the custom products at some point (as gifts
to my committee members when I defend), so please let me know if you are
planning on discontinuing the zazzle partnership.

I am also going to buy your firefly on a mug soon...it's a really cool
image.  



Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 13 Dec 2008 22:03:00 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: Picbreeder Status
> 
> Picbreeder usage is fairly consistent over the long term with
> occasional spikes caused by modest media exposure.   We have a few
> regulars who tend to produce a number of pictures in bursts and then
> return a few days or weeks later, and we also have a steady stream of
> new people who tend to come in, publish a few pictures, and then never
> publish anything again.  In terms of actual numbers, maybe about 10-25
> pictures are published each day.  There are almost 6,000 total
> published images after 1.5 years, so that gives you a sense of
> activity overall.  Daily activity has increased over that time, but
> not by that much.
> 
> Another interesting thing is that many more people visit and browse
> the site than actually publish something.  Another chunk of visitors
> save images privately but never publish them publicly (we can see how
> many images are saved that are not published).  It seems many people
> take public publishing seriously.
> 
> Branching does seem to lead to better images in people's opinion.
> Only 1.87% of the 482 top-rated images were evolved within 20
> generations.  So that would suggest that some level of complexity is
> correlated to quality.  However, it is also evident that some
> relatively simple pictures are quite appealing.  You can now look at
> complexity levels (in terms of nodes and connections) in the detailed
> view.  It is clear that some of the top-rated images are relatively
> the most complex.  For example this "planet" has almost 500
> connections: http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=5776
> 
> I think what people appreciate is (1) being able to recognize the
> image as something familiar, (2) complexity, (3) regularity.
> Interestingly, 2 and 3 are in conflict, which means you don't want too
> much of either (e.g. total irregularity means high complexity).  So I
> would say that there is some minimum level of complexity when things
> become compelling, and that beyond that other factors come into play.
>  Still, we may see a new order of complexity evolve if we wait long
> enough that is even more impressive.
> 
> About the custom products: This option is not popular at all.  People
> are simply not buying products based on these images.  That's okay to
> me because I like to show people the custom products option more
> because of the *ideas* it generates rather than to make money: People
> start to see the commercial potential of interactive evolution.  But
> the use of the option itself has been disappointing so far.  We do not
> know why that is.  Perhaps people don't realize it's available, or
> perhaps they are concerned with quality like you.  Or maybe they are
> waiting for the holidays :)  But I do think it's important to think
> about what it would take to get people to buy evolved products.
> 
> I did buy a shirt and a mug myself with Picbreeder images on them
> before we made the custom products option available to see what it
> would be like.  The quality was good in my opinion.  Zazzle gets
> ultra-high-resolution versions of the images (because CPPNs are in
> effect infinite resolution we can send them to Zazzle at any
> resolution) so they come out nice.  The images were properly
> integrated with the materials and haven't faded.  I am thinking of
> buying other stuff too.
> 
> ken
> 
>  
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "jeffreyclune" <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Hi Ken-
>> 
>> Out of curiosity, how is the picbreeder site coming? It appears to
> me that there is a
>> sustained level of activity, but I was wondering if you guys have
> looked at the stats lately.
>> Do you know about how many people actively use the site on a daily
> basis? Is use of the
>> site growing, steady, or did it see and early spike and is now
> trailing off?
>> 
>> I also recall that in early discussions of this site, you were
> curious to see if pictures would
>> become much better as the complexity of the networks grew due to the
> many increased 
>> generations that would be made possible by an active user base. Have
> you found that 
>> there is, say, a correlation between genome complexity and some
> success criteria (e.g.
>> rank or num_branches)?
>> 
>> The ability to purchase images on stuff like shirts and mugs is also
> cool. Have you found
>> that a lot of people are doing that? Also, I am thinking of doing so
> myself. Is the quality
>> pretty high? For example, does your firefly look good on a mug?
>> 
>> The reason I am asking is mostly curiosity. I am interested to know
> how much the general
>> public gets...and stays...engaged in these types of very cool,
> social, web 2.0 experiments.
>> 
>> 
>> Cheers,
>> Jeff
>> 
> 
>
